statement.text: The circle of Willis is an arterial anastomotic ring at the base of the brain connecting the anterior and posterior circulations, providing collateral protection that determines tolerance to carotid occlusion during surgery or disease.

explanation.intuition: The circle of Willis is a roundabout of blood vessels at the base of the brain. If one road in (carotid) is blocked, blood can detour through the roundabout to still reach all parts of the brain - if the roundabout is complete.
explanation.key_insight: Only 20-25% of people have a complete circle of Willis. Preoperative assessment of circle completeness (via CTA or MRA) helps predict tolerance to carotid clamping during CEA and risk of stroke.
explanation.technical_details: Components: anterior cerebral arteries (×2), anterior communicating artery, internal carotid arteries (×2), posterior communicating arteries (×2), posterior cerebral arteries (×2), basilar artery. Common variants: hypoplastic A1 (10%), absent AComm (5%), hypoplastic PComm (30%), fetal PCA (20%). Completeness: only 20-25% complete. Clinical relevance: incomplete circle increases risk during carotid clamping, may require shunting.

clinical_pearls: Only 20-25% have complete circle - most have some hypoplasia
Incomplete circle increases stroke risk during carotid clamping
Fetal PCA (20% of people) - PCA arises from ICA, not basilar
